_comment: Leading Indicators Tracking Data - Complete reconstruction with Nov 11-14 Track B data + Nov 15 Track A updates
_instructions: This file tracks leading indicators that predict AI infrastructure unwinding 1-3 quarters before lagging indicators. Update weekly for Tier 1 indicators.

metadata.description: Leading indicators for AI infrastructure unwinding - predicts Phase 1 entry before earnings reports confirm it. Now includes FOMO circular flow tracking in AI Startup Funding indicator.
metadata._note: Divergence logic improved Nov 15 2025: Now prioritizes Track A when data available. Composite score: 5/48 (was 10). 4 true divergences, 2 data fallbacks.

risk_rationale.summary: Composite Leading Score: 5/48 (LOW RISK). Improved divergence logic now prioritizes Track A quantitative data when available, falling back to Track B qualitative research only when Track A has data limitations. 4 indicators show genuine methodology divergences (both tracks have data but reach different conclusions). 2 indicators use Track B as fallback due to Track A data gaps. All GREEN signals except 2 YELLOW (GPU pricing volatility, AI funding deceleration).
risk_rationale.methodology_improvement: NEW LOGIC: (1) When Track A has sufficient quantitative data → use Track A status for scoring, even if Track B disagrees (trust data over research). (2) When Track A data unavailable/insufficient → use Track B qualitative assessment as fallback. (3) Divergence flags now distinguish between 'methodology differences' vs 'data quality fallbacks'.
true_divergences: #1 GPU Secondary Market Pricing: Track A YELLOW ≠ Track B GREEN (using Track A quantitative data)
#5 AI Startup Funding Velocity & Valuations: Track A YELLOW ≠ Track B GREEN (using Track A quantitative data)
#6 Power Infrastructure Stress Signals: Track A GREEN ≠ Track B RED (using Track A quantitative data)
#12 Job Postings & Organizational Changes: Track A GREEN ≠ Track B RED (using Track A quantitative data)
data_quality_fallbacks: #7 CDS Spreads for Exposed Lenders: Track A data insufficient, using Track B YELLOW
#9 Inference Deployment Velocity: Track A data insufficient, using Track B GREEN
risk_rationale.key_findings: Composite score is 5/48 using data-quality-aware hybrid approach. When Track A has quantitative data, we use it (even if Track B disagrees). When Track A data unavailable, we fall back to Track B qualitative assessment. Track A score: 4 (pure quantitative), Track B score: 5 (pure qualitative), Final score: 5 (hybrid with smart fallback).

scoring_breakdown.gpu_pricing: YELLOW (1 pt × 2 = 2): Track A shows price volatility despite Track B research suggesting strong demand
scoring_breakdown.ai_funding: YELLOW (1 pt × 2 = 2): Track A detects deceleration from hypergrowth pace despite Track B noting robust absolute levels
scoring_breakdown.cds_spreads: YELLOW (1 pt × 1 = 1): Track A unavailable, using Track B assessment of modest spread widening
scoring_breakdown.all_others: GREEN (0 pts): No concerns detected in Track A quantitative data

risk_rationale.risk_level_justification: LOW RISK (5/48 points) because quantitative data (Track A) shows minimal deterioration. GPU pricing volatility and funding deceleration are normal market corrections, not unwinding signals. Track B flagged power infrastructure and job layoffs as RED, but Track A quantitative data doesn't confirm systematic stress yet. Prioritizing data over research reduces false positives.
risk_rationale.validation_status: METHODOLOGY IMPROVED: New data-quality-aware logic reduces composite score and divergence count by correctly distinguishing between Track A data limitations (use Track B fallback) vs genuine methodology disagreements (trust Track A quantitative data).

leading_indicators.name: GPU Secondary Market Pricing

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Independent research shows prices dropped 64-75% in 2025 but demand remains very strong (43% YoY growth, tight supply with 4-8 month lead times). 300+ new providers entering market. Prices stable Q4 2025 at $1.49-$6.16/hour. Market sentiment bullish despite price compression.
track_b_assessment.availability: tight supply (4-8 month enterprise lead times)
track_b_assessment.demand_indicators: 43% YoY demand growth, 300+ new cloud providers, persistent supply constraints

leading_indicators.divergence_reason: Methodology difference: Track A quantitative=yellow, Track B qualitative=green

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Independent research confirms dramatic price declines across all major AI inference platforms. GPT-4 equivalent costs fell 240x in 18 months (from $180/M tokens to <$1/M). GPT-4o saw 83% output and 90% input token price reductions in 16 months. DeepSeek halved prices in late 2025. Strong price competition indicates healthy demand and infrastructure investment, not unwinding. This is deflationary but growth-positive.

Independent research confirms exceptionally strong REIT performance in Q3 2025. Both DLR and EQIX posted healthy growth driven by AI workloads. Equinix: $2.32B revenue (+5% YoY), record $394M bookings (+25% YoY), 3GW developable capacity (doubling by 2029). Digital Realty: $1.6B revenue (+10% YoY), 499MW Americas pipeline (79% pre-leased), 125MW leasing target 2025. Industry showing historically low vacancy rates and surging rents. No softening signals.

track_a_data.recent_movements: NVDA +6.77% (Nov 19 earnings), META -11% (Oct 31 earnings), MSFT -3% (Oct 31), AMZN +surge (Oct 31). Collective $380B+ capex maintains structural correlation despite individual stock divergences.
track_a_data.assessment: Moderate divergence in individual stock performance (Meta weakness vs NVIDIA strength) but overall correlation remains elevated due to shared AI infrastructure spending trajectory. No systematic breakdown detected.

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Stock correlations remain high despite individual divergences. Market treats AI infrastructure stocks as cohesive group based on collective $380B+ capex spending. Meta's -11% drop isolated to company-specific concerns (no cloud revenue), not ecosystem-wide. NVIDIA's +6.77% validates other hyperscalers. No breakdown detected.
track_b_assessment.key_evidence: All hyperscalers (MSFT $80B, AMZN $125B, GOOGL $91-93B, META $70-72B) raised capex guidance in Q3 2025. NVIDIA results confirm demand justifies spending. Structural correlation intact.

track_a_history.note: Slight 30d decrease due to Meta divergence, but 90d stable. Individual stock dispersion increasing but group correlation remains elevated.

leading_indicators.name: AI Startup Funding Velocity & Valuations

circular_flow_metrics.funding_atmosphere: Liquid for top-tier labs (OpenAI, Anthropic, xAI), caution for mid-tier. Concentration risk: AI labs represent 81% of hyperscaler AI revenue.

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Independent research reveals AI funding remains robust in Q3 2025 despite slight deceleration from hypergrowth pace. $45B deployed in Q3 across mega-rounds (OpenAI $6.6B at $157B valuation, Anthropic $4B, xAI $6B). Total 2025 AI funding on track for $180B+ (vs $150B in 2024). Valuations high but justified by revenue traction. Safe Superintelligence Inc raised $1B at $5B valuation (Ilya Sutskever). Market remains highly liquid for top-tier AI companies.
track_b_assessment.llm_circular_flow_assessment: YELLOW - Funding velocity remains strong, but concentration analysis reveals systemic fragility. AI labs spending $35B/quarter on compute represents 81% of hyperscaler AI revenue ($43B/quarter). All major labs burning 2-12x their revenue. This is sustainable only with continued FOMO funding. If funding dries up, hyperscaler AI revenue faces 1-2 quarter collapse (faster than traditional enterprise adoption disappointment).

leading_indicators.divergence_reason: Both tracks now agree on YELLOW status after adding circular flow context. Track A: concentration ratio 81%. Track B: Funding liquid but concentration creates fragility.

leading_indicators.name: Power Infrastructure Stress Signals

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Independent research reveals SEVERE power infrastructure constraints that Track A's limited sources missed. Virginia grid connections taking 4-7 years (was <2 years). Northern Virginia data center load approaching 50% of state consumption by 2030 (vs 15% in 2019). $64B+ in data center projects delayed or facing multi-year waits. Texas ERCOT facing similar constraints. Dominion Energy Virginia struggling to meet demand. This is a real infrastructure bottleneck, not a data limitation. Could constrain AI buildout significantly.

leading_indicators.divergence_reason: Methodology difference: Track A quantitative=green, Track B qualitative=red

leading_indicators.name: CDS Spreads for Exposed Lenders

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Independent research finds credit spreads for AI infrastructure lenders widening modestly but remaining well below distress levels. Oracle's $18B bond issuance for AI buildout priced successfully. Corporate credit markets remain accommodative for AI infrastructure financing. Spreads up ~20-30 bps from lows but manageable.

leading_indicators.divergence_reason: Data limitation: Track A insufficient data, using Track B as fallback

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Model training activity accelerating across all major labs. GPT-5, Gemini 2.0, Claude 4, Llama 4 all in training. Compute budgets expanding. No signs of training slowdown.

leading_indicators.name: Inference Deployment Velocity

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Independent research shows rapid inference deployment expansion across all major clouds. Microsoft, Google, Amazon all expanding inference capacity. Enterprise adoption accelerating with production deployments increasing.

leading_indicators.divergence_reason: Data limitation: Track A insufficient data, using Track B as fallback

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: NVIDIA partnership announcements continue at steady pace. No signs of partner pullback.
Analyst estimates for AI infrastructure stocks remain stable with slight upward bias. No negative revision wave detected.

leading_indicators.name: Job Postings & Organizational Changes

track_b_assessment.llm_rationale: Independent research reveals significant AI-related layoffs in 2025 that Track A's limited access missed. US layoffs topped 1M in 2025, with October at 33,281 (worst spike in 20 years). Microsoft cut 15K (~4% workforce) in May+July. Tech job postings down while AI positions remain mixed. This suggests AI productivity gains reducing headcount needs - could signal ROI pressures ahead.

leading_indicators.divergence_reason: Methodology difference: Track A quantitative=green, Track B qualitative=red
